ratings.question_text: Your level of engagement with the course was:
What is your overall assessment of this course?
The course was well organized to facilitate student learning.
I received clear feedback that improved my learning.
Relative to other courses you have taken at Yale, the level of intellectual challenge of this course was:
Relative to other courses you have taken at Yale, the workload of this course was:

narratives.question_text: What knowledge, skills, and insights did you develop by taking this course?
comments: root finding methods, numerical analysis methods, implementing numerical algorithms and the consequences of doing so, linear systems and their stability
I learned a few numerical methods.
Different numerical methods for root finding and systems of equations both by hand and using code.

I learned how about various methods for approximating solutions to problems which would otherwise be difficult to solve exactly. I learned why these methods works, how to apply them, how to optimize them, and how to analyze the error/accuracy. I also learned a lot about computational efficiency in programming.
Applying Numerical methods to real life problems
Numeric methods of solving linear algebra and calculus problems
We learned about various linear system solvers and methods for approximation.

narratives.question_text: What are the strengths and weaknesses of this course and how could it be improved?
comments: This course is extremely well-taught. There is just the right amount of background review for each topic that makes it accessible, but the pace and content are challenging. This has been one of my favorite courses, and Dr. Bennett is the highlight of the course.

This course needs to be modernized. First, it should be offered in Python. Second, WAY too much time is spent doing computational cost calculations on the board and on problem sets. We were not using big-O notation and instead tediously counting every addition, multiplication, or function evaluation; for an "applied" course, this was completely useless! Instead, teach us to time-test our code using more or less efficient methods! There should also be 2-fewer problem sets; having 1 due the Tuesday after Thanksgiving as well as the Tuesday of reading week is a little much; even though it's technically within the academic guidelines, it took up time and mental space during Thanksgiving break and is not in the spirit of these rules.

The homework is also graded strangely; the problems are rather easy but they knit-pick points for things that are not at the heart of the problem. I'd prefer harder problems with grading that correlates more closely with understanding than going to office hours and learning the tiny details you need to include to get full credit. Also far too much time copy-and-pasting a code's output (give us a required format and make an autograder!!!).

None of this is to say Professor Bennett is not amazing; she is, and is one of the reasons I took this course. She cares about her students and their learning. However, I see this as an essential course for modern engineers, and one of the few courses that could make small changes for large value improvements.

Strengths: the instructor and the coding assignments. The content is interesting but can be a little slow towards the end. The exams are hard but fair
Weaknesses: Explores interesting methods but it is not the cutting edge. Would be more interesting going deeper into individual ideas.

Strengths: the professor (Prof. Bennett) and the organization of the course. It is extremely well organized, and the Canvas page is feature complete, with class recordings, assignments, grades, files, etc all on there and easy to access. Pset and exam expectations were clear and the course overall was very well structured. 

Weaknesses: Some of the psets were a bit tedious and repetitive, and many of the parts had small details within the instructions that were not hard to miss and get a couple points here and there off.
Great course, no notes
The lectures were very organized and even though most of the material was new to us it was not difficult to start to learn because of the way the material was presented.

narratives.question_text: Would you recommend this course to another student? Please explain.
comments: I would. It's a ton of work but the content is interesting and Dr. Bennett sets you up to do well if you're willing to put in the time and effort.
Yes, but please, don't use MATLAB. Take it in C++ and practice a language you might use outside of research.
If you enjoy the math aspect and want to work on coding, it is interesting and teaches good methods, but it is not the most thrilling course as far as pushing your math ability to the limit.

Yes, if taught by Prof. Bennett. It is a really interesting course and very fair, and Prof. Bennett is really so good at teaching it. She is great during lecture and office hours and the small class size really facilitates learning the material well. She is kind and helpful and very knowledgable about the material and knows exactly how to convey it so everyone understands. The psets were tough and sometimes tedious but fair, but beware the the exams are pretty difficult yet the course is graded fairly to accommodate for that.
Yes
A lot of work, but very rewarding in the end
Yes - it is a great engineering elective and is very engaging if you put the time into it.
